Award.AbstractNarration:
Bauman
DMS-1109459

The goal of the project is the analysis of mathematical models described by nonlinear partial differential equations describing liquid crystal and superconducting materials, focusing on thin liquid crystal films, ferro-electric liquid crystal materials, polar-modulated liquid crystal materials such as bent-core fibers, and high-temperature superconducting materials. The investigators identify qualitative features of solutions to the mathematical models describing these phenomena, including pattern formation of various phases of the materials and the location, nature, and number of defects. The models are highly nonlinear and expressed in terms of nonconvex, second-order energies. Developing methods in partial differential equations to analyze these features is part of the project.

The project is related to applications in materials. For example, physicists have proposed to build lattices of colloidal particles by coating each with a thin film of liquid crystal material in such a way that the film's defects act as natural bonding sites (i.e., chemical linking locations) between the particles. This self-assembly allows the creation of functionalized micron-sized objects similar to the molecules characteristic of organic chemistry, which can be used for particle-based bioassays and catalysis, and for photonic band-gap materials. Ferro-electric liquid crystals are used to make optical switches, nano-devices, and displays. Liquid crystal bent-core fibers have been proposed by physicists to model artificial muscles and other biological applications. High-temperature superconductors are used for small-scale sensors such as squids (superconducting quantum interference detectors) and to make powerful magnets. The project takes up the mathematical investigation of models for these applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project the PIs and their students were able to characterize and identify signature patterns and structures in the  solutions to mathematical models used for describing soft matter systems; they further developed analytic techniques for investigating the partial differential equations used in the models' formulations.  The systems  explored include models for liquid crystals, elastomers, and superconductors.   A common feature of these materials is that they respond to applied stresses such as changes in temperature, applied electro-magnetic fields, or mechanical loads by passing through a hierarchy of ordered phases with highly distinct electrical and optical conductivities or elastic moduli. In the case of a liquid crystal material its molecules form phase dependent patterns that include particular types of vacancies or defects. Materials scientists use these inhomogeneities as  building blocks  to  develop materials with prescribed optical and/or electromagnetic properties. For the case of nematic thin films the PIs showed that the defect pattern consists of a discrete number of filaments, they determined the number and relative locations of the filaments in samples and established the distinctive  1/2- degree texture of the liquid crystal material near each filament. At lower temperatures liquid crystals are in a smectic phase with a finely layered structure. D. Phillips and his students characterized  point singularities and bends (chevrons) in the layering. These defects induce bi-stable equilibrium states and the phenomenon of switching between states was invetigated as well. P. Bauman and her Ph.D. student  investigated the asymptotic behavior of minimizers of the Lawrence-Doniach model, which describes high-temperature superconductors as layered superconductorswith nonlinear Josephson coupling between the layers. The behavior of defects (vortices) and the induced magnetic field in this case are shown to depend strongly on the direction of the applied magnetic field as well as its modulus compared to the Ginzburg-Landau parameter. In this project, analyzing the behavior of stable solutions including their defects requires an expanded analytic theory which has lead to different types of questions and the development of new analytic techniques. An underlying theme has been to find effective limiting energies which are more tractable to analyze.  A principal impact of this investigation on the discipline is the expansion and development of methods to carry out these analyses and ways to measure the difference between the solutions for the limiting energies and those for the original energies.

Four PhD investigations were carried out and supported as part of  this project. As part of of the project the graduate students were guided in  carying out research and presenting their findings at meetings and in print. The four students have graduated and now have post graduate positions in teaching and research.
